titleStmt.title: A Breif Description of James Weldon Johnson
titleStmt.author: Unknown

publicationStmt.p: This document forms part of the project "Editing the Eartha M.M. White Archive" at the University of North Florida.

msIdentifier.repository: University of North Florida, Thomas G. Carpenter Library Special Collections and Archives

objectDesc.p: This two-page document is typed in blue ink on letter size paper.

editorialDecl.p: This file was transcribed and encoded according to the editorial criteria of the project "Editing the Eartha M.M. White Archive." Using the various options encoded within <choice> elements, this file enables the viewing of a diplomatic transcription and a regularized reading text.

body.p:
James Weldon Johnson, born in Jacksonville, Florida in 1871 and died in Maine,
June 26, 1938. His father was Rev. James Johnson of Virginia. His mother Ellen
Louise Johnson of Nassau. His grandmother, Mary Barton. He was the second child
of a family of three. A sister died in infancy before he was born. His brother
Rosemond who still lives, residing in N. Y. He attended Stanton High School30.352255 -81.673036 in
this City under Dr. D. W. Culp and later Mr. Autherl. After finishing Stanton30.352255 -81.673036 he
attended school in Atlanta , returning to Jacksonville, he bacame a teacher in the
Stanton School30.352255 -81.673036 as assistant to Mr. Authel. The school being an elementary school
at the time. It was during his administration as principal of the school that he
hr he made it a high school which was the first and only high school for Negroes in
the city. He liked the profession of teaching but owing to the fact at that time all
this county would pay a principal was $125 dollars. He felt that he might seek something
better do he took the practice of law and later was appointed United States Council
of Nicarauga, Venezuela and the Azores.

The Lincoln Douglas Memorial Association had organized to carry out a three fold
purpose to see that Emancipation Day, Memorial BDay and Lincoln Birthday are celebrated.
I invited Mr. Johnson to speak on this Lincoln Birthday program. He said it was at
this participating in this program that gave him the inspiration to write the Negro
National AthemnAnthem.

I like to think of some of his friends and associates that I know obof beginning
with Samuel Grant, Estelle Love, Mamie Stewart, Carrie Llloyd, J.W. Wetmore, Dr.
Arthur Wall Smith and of the dearest, J. Settiers. I like to think of the girl that
everyone thought he would marry, Jannie Grant who went to Tallahassee while he was in
Atlanta and before he was the Godfather of one of her girls. I like to think of him
singing in the choir of Ebenez er Church30.404934 -81.721208 with his mother. I like to think of him as
President of the Duval County Teachers and now
a s a little financial hint, these brothers thought they moved from Jacksonville
to the n North sent their earning to their father to bank and invest. This he did
by putting most of it in the Jacksonville Development Company and during extreme illness
of Rev. Johnson this company went into bankruptcy and very near 50,000 dollars of
their earnings were lost. Rev. James Johnson passes not knowing the company had
failed and he had lost nearly 50,000 dollars. This was one of the things that caused
both brothers to dislike Florida.

His brother Rosmond of course was the one I was most interested in because during
those days there was no one like Rosmond. All the girls used to tease him about his
name, Rosey. This was given because he was expected to be a girl, but he took it
very good naturally.

I like to think of his brother by the last letter that I received from his with
this poem enclosed.

p.hi:
There is a word on every tongue,
That speaks of friends most dear;
In English tis "Forget me not",
In French La Souvenier.

body.note:
(Is it possible that a page is missing from this MS? Margin of page 1
was to far right on original but reads like page missing)
